Graphical abstract

Anion-dependent four Cd(II) coordination polymers 1D chain [Cd(btb)(H2O)2(NO3)2] n  (1), threefold interpenetrated diamondoid network {[Cd(btb)2(H2O)2](BF4)2} n  (2), threefold interpenetrated α-polonium cubic network {[Cd(btb)3](ClO4)2} n  (3) and {[Cd(btb)3](PF6)2} n  (4) were synthesized using the flexible ligand 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)butane (btb). Compounds 1, 2, 3 and 4 exhibit blue luminescent emissions maxima at 439, 426, 422 and 424nm, respectively, in the solid state at room temperature. The frameworks of 2, 3, 4 maintain stable up to 240°C.

elements.clean_text:
Abstract

The self-assembly reactions of the flexible ligand 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)butane (btb) and Cd(II) salts with different anions     NO   3   -    ,     BF   4   -    ,     ClO   4   -    ,     PF   6   -     give 1D chain [Cd(btb)(H2O)2(NO3)2] n  (1), threefold interpenetrated diamondoid network {[Cd(btb)2(H2O)2](BF4)2} n  (2), threefold interpenetrated α-polonium cubic network {[Cd(btb)3](ClO4)2} n  (3) and {[Cd(btb)3](PF6)2} n  (4). Compounds 1, 2, 3 and 4 exhibit blue luminescent emission maxima at 439, 426, 422 and 424nm, respectively, in the solid state at room temperature. The frameworks of 2, 3, 4 maintain stable when 2, 3, 4 are kept at 240°C at vacuum for 2h.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In the past decade, great attention has paid to the design and construction of coordination polymers for their potential application as well as the variety of architectures and topologies . The design of the coordination polymers is highly influenced by several factors such as the coordination geometry of the central atom, the structural characteristics of the ligand, the solvent system and the counter anion. The selection of appropriate ligands as “building blocks” is undoubtedly the key point in manipulating the network structures of the coordination polymers. The bifunctional flexible ligands with conformational flexibility can induce variability of structure and may lead to the formation of supramolecular isomers . The anions serve more than merely balancing the charges of a cationic complex and influence the structure of a supramolecular system through coordination to the metal . Dunbar and coworkers reported that the reaction of 3,6-di(2-pyridyl)-1,2,4,5-tetrazine with first-row transition metals could yield a molecular square and a pentagon with one anion accommodated in the cavities of the polygons. In this case, anions function as templates through anion–π interactions .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In the past decade, great attention has paid to the design and construction of coordination polymers for their potential application as well as the variety of architectures and topologies . The design of the coordination polymers is highly influenced by several factors such as the coordination geometry of the central atom, the structural characteristics of the ligand, the solvent system and the counter anion. The selection of appropriate ligands as "building blocks" is undoubtedly the key point in manipulating the network structures of the coordination polymers. The bifunctional flexible ligands with conformational flexibility can induce variability of structure and may lead to the formation of supramolecular isomers . The anions serve more than merely balancing the charges of a cationic complex and influence the structure of a supramolecular system through coordination to the metal . Dunbar and coworkers reported that the reaction of 3,6-di(2-pyridyl)-1,2,4,5-tetrazine with first-row transition metals could yield a molecular square and a pentagon with one anion accommodated in the cavities of the polygons. In this case, anions function as templates through anion-π interactions .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The ligands 1,2,4-triazole and its derivatives have received a great attention because of their intriguing structures and unique properties . Our interest is to study the coordination chemistry of 1,2,4-triazole and its derivatives together with their potential application in material science. Recently, we reported the crystal structures of a series of transition metal coordination polymers with the flexible bis(triazole) ligands such as 1,2-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)ethane  and 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene . 1,4-Bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)butane (btb) is a more flexible long ligand and can construct novel topologies . In order to investigate the influence of the flexibility of ligand molecule and the counter anion on the architecture of coordination polymers, we report in this paper the self-assembly reactions of the flexible ligand 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)butane (btb) and Cd(II) salts with different anions <mml:math altimg="si5.gif" overflow="scroll">

elements.clean_text: The ligands 1,2,4-triazole and its derivatives have received a great attention because of their intriguing structures and unique properties . Our interest is to study the coordination chemistry of 1,2,4-triazole and its derivatives together with their potential application in material science. Recently, we reported the crystal structures of a series of transition metal coordination polymers with the flexible bis(triazole) ligands such as 1,2-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)ethane  and 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene . 1,4-Bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)butane (btb) is a more flexible long ligand and can construct novel topologies . In order to investigate the influence of the flexibility of ligand molecule and the counter anion on the architecture of coordination polymers, we report in this paper the self-assembly reactions of the flexible ligand 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)butane (btb) and Cd(II) salts with different anions     NO   3   -    ,     BF   4   -    ,     ClO   4   -    ,     PF   6   -     and obtain the 1D chain [Cd(btb)(H2O)2(NO3)2] n  (1), threefold interpenetrated diamondoid network {[Cd(btb)2(H2O)2](BF4)2} n  (2), threefold interpenetrated α-polonium cubic network {[Cd(btb)3](ClO4)2} n  (3) and {[Cd(btb)3](PF6)2} n  (4).

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Coordination polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
 was synthesized by the slow diffusion method in CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH/H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O medium. The crystal structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
 shows that each Cd(II) atom displays a distorted octahedral coordination geometry, coordinated by four oxygen atoms from two water and two nitrate ions, and two triazole nitrogen atoms from two btb ligands (). The bridging btb ligands link the Cd(II) atoms to from the 1D chain. The btb ligand shows the completely <ce:italic>anti</ce:italic> (<ce:italic>anti</ce:italic>–<ce:italic>anti</ce:italic>–<ce:italic>anti</ce:italic>) conformation. The Cd⋯Cd distance separation by btb is 12.7962(26)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. There are intra and inter-chain hydrogen bonding interactions between coordination water molecules and nitrite anions ().</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Coordination polymer 1  was synthesized by the slow diffusion method in CH3OH/H2O medium. The crystal structure of 1  shows that each Cd(II) atom displays a distorted octahedral coordination geometry, coordinated by four oxygen atoms from two water and two nitrate ions, and two triazole nitrogen atoms from two btb ligands (). The bridging btb ligands link the Cd(II) atoms to from the 1D chain. The btb ligand shows the completely anti (anti-anti-anti) conformation. The Cd⋯Cd distance separation by btb is 12.7962(26)Å. There are intra and inter-chain hydrogen bonding interactions between coordination water molecules and nitrite anions ().

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> exhibits a threefold interpenetrated diamondoid network (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>). The coordination geometry of the Cd(II) atom is a distorted octahedral, formed equatorially by four nitrogen atoms from four symmetry-related btb ligands, and axially by two water molecules (). The alkane carbon atoms of btb are disordered. The four bridges formed by four btb ligands do not form a plane. Each Cd(II) centre connects four Cd(II) centres through four btb bridges in a tetrahedral mode. Therefore each Cd(II) centre constitutes a tetrahedral second building unit (a, ). The extension of the structure into a 3D network is accomplished by connecting four btb ligands to the tetrahedral building block (). The Cd⋯Cd distances separated by btb bridges are 12.6154(18)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The topological analysis of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> reveals that it is a typically diamondoid framework containing large adamantanoid cages (b). Because the single diamondoid network has large spacious voids, it allows two more identical diamondoid networks to interpenetrate giving rise to a threefold interpenetrating network (c), with <mml:math altimg="si9.gif" overflow="scroll">

elements.clean_text: Compound 2 exhibits a threefold interpenetrated diamondoid network ( ). The coordination geometry of the Cd(II) atom is a distorted octahedral, formed equatorially by four nitrogen atoms from four symmetry-related btb ligands, and axially by two water molecules (). The alkane carbon atoms of btb are disordered. The four bridges formed by four btb ligands do not form a plane. Each Cd(II) centre connects four Cd(II) centres through four btb bridges in a tetrahedral mode. Therefore each Cd(II) centre constitutes a tetrahedral second building unit (a, ). The extension of the structure into a 3D network is accomplished by connecting four btb ligands to the tetrahedral building block (). The Cd⋯Cd distances separated by btb bridges are 12.6154(18)Å. The topological analysis of 2 reveals that it is a typically diamondoid framework containing large adamantanoid cages (b). Because the single diamondoid network has large spacious voids, it allows two more identical diamondoid networks to interpenetrate giving rise to a threefold interpenetrating network (c), with     BF   4   -     anions occupying the gap. There are hydrogen bonding interactions between coordination water molecules and F atoms of     BF   4   -     anions.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Compounds <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> have a similar threefold interpenetrating 3D α-polonium cubic network (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>). Three are two in dependent Cd(II) atoms and the ratio of Cd(1)/Cd(2) is 2:1 in complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> (). Three are four in dependent Cd(II) atoms bridged by btb ligands in complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> (). Each Cd(II) atom is six-coordinated to six triazole nitrogen atoms of six btb ligands. Each Cd(II) atom is bridged to six neighboring Cd(II) centres via six btb ligands, forming 3D α-polonium cubic network (a, ). The btb ligand shows the completely <ce:italic>anti</ce:italic> (<ce:italic>anti–anti–anti</ce:italic>) conformation in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>. The Cd⋯Cd distances separated by btb bridges are all 14.0685<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, but 14.1552(24), 14.1875(24) and 14.4132(19)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å in <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>. Moreover, three identical 3D network structures are still mutually self-interpenetrated to generate the threefold interpenetrating 3D α-polonium cubic network because of the porous nature of the single network (b). Though threefold interpenetrating networks exist, microporous channels are still found, which are accommodated by <mml:math altimg="si11.gif" overflow="scroll">

elements.clean_text: Compounds 3 and 4 have a similar threefold interpenetrating 3D α-polonium cubic network ( ). Three are two in dependent Cd(II) atoms and the ratio of Cd(1)/Cd(2) is 2:1 in complex 3 (). Three are four in dependent Cd(II) atoms bridged by btb ligands in complex 4 (). Each Cd(II) atom is six-coordinated to six triazole nitrogen atoms of six btb ligands. Each Cd(II) atom is bridged to six neighboring Cd(II) centres via six btb ligands, forming 3D α-polonium cubic network (a, ). The btb ligand shows the completely anti (anti-anti-anti) conformation in 3 and 4. The Cd⋯Cd distances separated by btb bridges are all 14.0685Å in 3, but 14.1552(24), 14.1875(24) and 14.4132(19)Å in 4. Moreover, three identical 3D network structures are still mutually self-interpenetrated to generate the threefold interpenetrating 3D α-polonium cubic network because of the porous nature of the single network (b). Though threefold interpenetrating networks exist, microporous channels are still found, which are accommodated by     ClO   4   -     anions in 3 and     PF   6   -     anions in 4.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The solid state luminescence spectra of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> and the free btb ligand at room temperature are studied (). Compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> reveal the emission maxima at approximately 439, 426, 422 and 424<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, upon excitation at 360<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. In comparison, free btb molecule in the solid state displays an emission band centred at about 405<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm when excited at 340<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. The emissions of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> can be attributed to the emission of ligand-to-metal charge-transfer (LMCT) .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The solid state luminescence spectra of 1, 2, 3, 4 and the free btb ligand at room temperature are studied (). Compounds 1, 2, 3 and 4 reveal the emission maxima at approximately 439, 426, 422 and 424nm, upon excitation at 360nm. In comparison, free btb molecule in the solid state displays an emission band centred at about 405nm when excited at 340nm. The emissions of 1-4 can be attributed to the emission of ligand-to-metal charge-transfer (LMCT) .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Thermal analysis of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows that the coordinated water molecules are lost in a continuous fashion from 80 to 160<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (). The anhydrous {[Cd(btb)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> is stable up to 251<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Compounds <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are stable up to 274 and 276<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, respectively (). When <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are kept at 240<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C at vacuum for 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h, the frameworks of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> maintain stable which were confirmed by XPRD measurement and the simulation from the X-ray data for the single crystals ().</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Thermal analysis of 2 shows that the coordinated water molecules are lost in a continuous fashion from 80 to 160°C (). The anhydrous {[Cd(btb)2](BF4)2} n  is stable up to 251°C. Compounds 3 and 4 are stable up to 274 and 276°C, respectively (). When 2, 3, 4 are kept at 240°C at vacuum for 2h, the frameworks of 2, 3, 4 maintain stable which were confirmed by XPRD measurement and the simulation from the X-ray data for the single crystals ().

elements.clean_text: Four Cd(II) coordination polymers were synthesized by the self-assembly reactions of the flexible ligand 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)butane (btb) and Cd(II) salts with different anions, i.e.     NO   3   -    ,     BF   4   -    ,     ClO   4   -    ,     PF   6   -    . The structures are dependent on the anions. The shape and size of anions may play the key roles in the self-assembly of the coordination polymers. The coordinating anion     NO   3   -     yields the 1D chain of 1. The non-coordinating tetrahedral     BF   4   -     gives rise to the formation of a threefold interpenetrated diamondoid network of 2. The use of the non-coordinating relatively bigger tetrahedral     ClO   4   -     and octahedral     PF   6   -     result in the formation of the threefold interpenetrated α-polonium cubic network of 3 and 4. On the basis of this work, further syntheses and structural studies of novel coordination polymers with flexible bis(triazole) ligands are also under way in our laboratory.

<ce:simple-para view="all">Synthesis of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>: A 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml aqueous solution of Cd(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (1.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) or Cd(BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (1.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) or Cd(ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (1.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) or Cd(PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (1.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was added to a tube, then a 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH solution of 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)butane (btb) (1.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was slowly added to tube above the aqueous solution. Colorless crystals <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (yield: 52%), <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (yield: 58%), <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> (yield: 64%) and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> (yield: 61%) were obtained after about 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>weeks. Anal. Calcd. for C<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>CdN<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>): C, 20.68; H, 3.47; N, 24.12%. Found: C, 20.47; H, 3.36; N, 23.95. Anal. Calcd. for C<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">28</ce:inf>B<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CdF<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>): C, 27.20; H, 3.99; N, 23.80%. Found: C, 27.03; H, 3.86; N, 23.62. Anal. Calcd. for C<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">36</ce:inf>CdCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>): C, 32.46; H, 4.09; N, 28.40%. Found: C, 32.31; H, 3.95; N, 28.26. Anal. Calcd. for C<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">36</ce:inf>CdF<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>): C, 29.44; H, 3.71; N, 25.76%. Found: C, 29.28; H, 3.58; N, 25.63.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text: Synthesis of 1, 2, 3 and 4: A 10ml aqueous solution of Cd(NO3)2 ⋅6H2O (1.0mmol) or Cd(BF4)2 (1.0mmol) or Cd(ClO4)2 (1.0mmol) or Cd(PF6)2 (1.0mmol) was added to a tube, then a 10ml CH3OH solution of 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)butane (btb) (1.0mmol) was slowly added to tube above the aqueous solution. cln_elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">Anion-dependent four Cd(II) coordination polymers 1D chain [Cd(btb)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), threefold interpenetrated diamondoid network {[Cd(btb)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), threefold interpenetrated α-polonium cubic network {[Cd(btb)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>](ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) and {[Cd(btb)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>](PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>) were synthesized using the flexible ligand 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)butane (btb). Compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> exhibit blue luminescent emissions maxima at 439, 426, 422 and 424<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, respectively, in the solid state at room temperature. The frameworks of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> maintain stable up to 240<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C.</ce:simple-para><ce:para view="all">The solid state luminescence spectra of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> and the free btb ligand at room temperature are studied (). Compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> reveal the emission maxima at approximately 439, 426, 422 and 424<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, upon excitation at 360<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. In comparison, free btb molecule in the solid state displays an emission band centred at about 405<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm when excited at 340<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. The emissions of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> can be attributed to the emission of ligand-to-metal charge-transfer (LMCT) .</ce:para><ce:para view="all">Thermal analysis of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows that the coordinated water molecules are lost in a continuous fashion from 80 to 160<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (). The anhydrous {[Cd(btb)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> is stable up to 251<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Compounds <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are stable up to 274 and 276<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, respectively (). When <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are kept at 240<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C at vacuum for 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h, the frameworks of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> maintain stable which were confirmed by XPRD measurement and the simulation from the X-ray data for the single crystals ().</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Anion-dependent four Cd(II) coordination polymers 1D chain [Cd(btb)(H2O)2(NO3)2] n  (1), threefold interpenetrated diamondoid network {[Cd(btb)2(H2O)2](BF4)2} n  (2), threefold interpenetrated α-polonium cubic network {[Cd(btb)3](ClO4)2} n  (3) and {[Cd(btb)3](PF6)2} n  (4) were synthesized using the flexible ligand 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)butane (btb). Compounds 1, 2, 3 and 4 exhibit blue luminescent emissions maxima at 439, 426, 422 and 424nm, respectively, in the solid state at room temperature. The frameworks of 2, 3, 4 maintain stable up to 240°C.

The solid state luminescence spectra of 1, 2, 3, 4 and the free btb ligand at room temperature are studied (). Compounds 1, 2, 3 and 4 reveal the emission maxima at approximately 439, 426, 422 and 424nm, upon excitation at 360nm. In comparison, free btb molecule in the solid state displays an emission band centred at about 405nm when excited at 340nm. The emissions of 1-4 can be attributed to the emission of ligand-to-metal charge-transfer (LMCT) .

Thermal analysis of 2 shows that the coordinated water molecules are lost in a continuous fashion from 80 to 160°C (). The anhydrous {[Cd(btb)2](BF4)2} n  is stable up to 251°C. Compounds 3 and 4 are stable up to 274 and 276°C, respectively (). When 2, 3, 4 are kept at 240°C at vacuum for 2h, the frameworks of 2, 3, 4 maintain stable which were confirmed by XPRD measurement and the simulation from the X-ray data for the single crystals ().
